definition: Kind and helpful; wanting to do good for others.
examples: A benevolent neighbour brought soup to the family.
The benevolent fund supports students in need.

definition: Permission for something to happen; to give permission or agree.
examples: Parents’ consent is required for the trip. (noun)
She consented to share her notes. (verb)

definition: Careful about what you say or do, to keep something private or to avoid embarrassment.
examples: Be discreet when discussing grades.
A discreet nod signalled it was time to go.

definition: To absorb all the attention or interest of someone.
examples: The puzzle engrossed the whole class.
She was engrossed in her book.

extra.memory_tip: Engross = your mind is ‘in gross’—fully taken.

definition: Respect and admiration; to regard highly.
examples: She is held in high esteem by her peers. (noun)
They esteemd the coach for his fairness. (verb)

definition: To make something seem larger, better, or worse than it really is.
examples: He exaggerated the size of the fish.
Try not to exaggerate the problem.

extra.memory_tip: Exaggerate = add extra to the facts.

definition: Large in amount or area; covering a wide range.
examples: The library has an extensive collection.
Floods caused extensive damage.

definition: Extremely good; also very imaginative or unrealistic.
examples: You did a fantastic job on the poster!
The film’s creatures were fantastic and strange.

extra.memory_tip: Fantastic = like fantasy or just fantastic quality.

definition: To arouse curiosity or interest; a secret plan or mysterious affair.
examples: The strange footprints intrigued the campers. (verb)
The novel was full of political intrigue. (noun)

definition: Something that causes wonder; to feel or express wonder.
examples: The new bridge is an engineering marvel. (noun)
We marvelled at the night sky. (verb)

definition: An important task or goal; a journey with a purpose.
examples: The rescue team’s mission was to find survivors.
Our mission this term is to reduce waste.

extra.memory_tip: Mission = what you’re sent to do.

definition: A good chance to do something.
examples: This internship is a great opportunity.
Don’t miss the opportunity to ask questions.

definition: To give up or let go of something, often unwillingly.
examples: He relinquished control of the project.
They reluctantly relinquished their claim.

extra.memory_tip: Relinquish = release your link to it.

examples: The tyrant silenced all critics.
Stories warn of tyrants who abuse power.

extra.memory_tip: Tyrant = tries to rule with terror.

definition: To defeat completely in battle or competition.
examples: The team vanquished their rivals.
Legends tell of heroes who vanquish monsters.
